title: Erdős Problem #155: Slow Growth of Maximum Sidon Subsets
description: Let F(N) be the largest Sidon subset of {1,...,N}. Is F(N+k) ≤ F(N)+1 for all sufficiently large N, for every fixed k? Possibly even for k ≈ ε√N. F(N) ~ √N. Status: OPEN.

sections.title: Core Definitions
sections.summary: Define IsSidonSet, maxSidonSize F(N), achievability and optimality.

sections.title: Monotonicity
sections.summary: F is monotone nondecreasing and increases by at most 1 per step.

sections.title: Asymptotic Bounds
sections.summary: Erdős–Turán upper bound F(N) ≤ √N + N^{1/4} + 1 and lower bound F(N) ≥ (1-o(1))√N.

sections.title: Main and Stronger Conjectures
sections.summary: F(N+k) ≤ F(N)+1 for fixed k and large N. Stronger form: k ≈ ε√N.

sections.title: Consequences and Small Values
sections.summary: Increase points are sparse (density ~√N). Known values: F(1)=1, ..., F(18)=6.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem around 1992, building on the classical Erdős–Turán (1941) study of Sidon sets. The function F(N) measures the largest B₂ subset of {1,...,N}. While F(N) ~ √N is well-established, the fine structure of its growth — whether F can jump by more than 1 over intervals of fixed length — remains unknown.
overview.problemStatement: Is it true that for every k ≥ 1, F(N+k) ≤ F(N) + 1 for all sufficiently large N, where F(N) is the maximum Sidon subset size of {1,...,N}?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize Sidon sets, define F(N) axiomatically, state the Erdős–Turán asymptotic bounds, and present both the basic conjecture (fixed k) and the stronger form (k ≈ ε√N). We also state consequences about the sparsity of increase points.
keyInsights: A Sidon (B₂) set has all pairwise sums distinct: |S| ≤ √N + O(N^{1/4})
F(N) ~ √N, so F increases by 1 about √N times in {1,...,N}
The conjecture says F plateaus on every fixed-length interval for large N
The stronger form suggests plateaus of length ~ε√N between increases

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #155 asks whether the maximum Sidon subset function F(N) grows so slowly that F(N+k) ≤ F(N)+1 for any fixed k and large N. This captures the intuition that F increases by 1 very rarely. The problem remains open, with a stronger variant suggesting plateaus of length ~ε√N.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would provide fine structural information about the distribution of Sidon sets, complementing the classical Erdős–Turán asymptotics. It would show that the 'next' larger Sidon set requires a substantial expansion of the interval.
openQuestions: Does F(N+k) ≤ F(N)+1 hold for all fixed k and large N?
Does the stronger form with k ≈ ε√N hold?
What is the exact threshold: the largest k(N) such that F(N+k(N)) ≤ F(N)+1?
Can the gap F(N) - √N be determined more precisely?
